HomePage.welcomeDescription: Your go-to platform for everything related to freshwater fish and aquatic plants. Whether you're just starting or a seasoned aquarist, we have the resources to help you create a thriving aquatic environment.

highlights.item1: Comprehensive species profiles with detailed care guides.
highlights.item2: Expert advice on maintaining a healthy aquarium.
highlights.item3: Tips for setting up your own virtual aquarium.

AboutPage.title: About Israquarium
AboutPage.introduction: Israquarium is your go-to resource for all things related to freshwater fish and aquatic plants. Whether you're an aquarium enthusiast, a professional aquarist, or someone just starting their journey into the world of aquatic life, Israquarium provides a wealth of knowledge to help you maintain thriving ecosystems.
AboutPage.missionDescription: At Israquarium, we believe that understanding the delicate balance of an aquarium ecosystem is key to maintaining healthy and vibrant fish and plants. We provide detailed and carefully curated information about a wide variety of freshwater species. Our mission is to empower aquarium owners with the tools and knowledge they need to create sustainable aquatic environments in their homes or businesses.

offerList.item1: Comprehensive species profiles for freshwater fish and plants.
offerList.item2: Guides for setting up and maintaining a healthy aquarium environment.
offerList.item3: Best practices for feeding, cleaning, and monitoring water quality.
offerList.item4: Tips and recommendations for dealing with common aquarium challenges.

AboutPage.offerDescription: Our platform is designed with hobbyists and professionals alike, providing the depth of information that can support both beginners and experienced aquarists.
AboutPage.globalDescription1: We believe that everyone should have access to reliable, educational resources about aquarium care, regardless of where they live or what language they speak. That's why Israquarium is available in multiple languages, including Hebrew, English, and Russian. Our goal is to make high-quality aquarium care knowledge accessible to a global audience.
AboutPage.globalDescription2: Whether you're in Israel or anywhere else in the world, you can count on Israquarium to provide accurate, detailed, and easy-to-understand content to guide you through your aquarium journey.
AboutPage.whyChooseUsDescription1: Israquarium stands out as a trusted resource for aquarium enthusiasts and experts alike. Our focus on freshwater species, paired with our commitment to providing multilingual resources, ensures that you have access to the most reliable and up-to-date information, no matter where you are or what your level of experience may be.
AboutPage.whyChooseUsDescription2: Join our growing community of aquarium lovers and take the next step in your aquatic journey. Whether you're learning how to start an aquarium or troubleshooting an issue with your fish or plants, Israquarium has the resources to help.

PrivacyPolicy.title: Privacy Policy
PrivacyPolicy.introduction: At Israquarium, your privacy is of utmost importance to us. This Privacy Policy outlines how we collect, use, and protect your personal information when you visit and interact with our website. By using our website, you agree to the practices described in this policy.
PrivacyPolicy.personalInfoDescription: When you register for an account on Israquarium, we may collect the following personal information:
PrivacyPolicy.personalInfoItem4: Preferences for notifications (feeding and cleaning reminders)
PrivacyPolicy.personalInfoItem5: Details about your aquarium, including fish species, feeding schedules, and cleaning schedules
PrivacyPolicy.virtualAquariumDescription: Users can create and maintain a virtual aquarium on our platform, including details like fish species, feeding schedules, and cleaning times. This data is stored in your account for tracking purposes.
PrivacyPolicy.nonPersonalInfoDescription: We collect non-personal information such as browser type, language preference, referring site, and the date and time of each visitor request. This information helps us understand how visitors use our website and improve our services.
PrivacyPolicy.usageDescription: The information we collect is used for the following purposes:
PrivacyPolicy.usageItem1: Account creation and management, including your virtual aquarium and fish cards
PrivacyPolicy.usageItem2: Sending email notifications about feeding and cleaning schedules (if opted-in)
PrivacyPolicy.usageItem3: Responding to inquiries or providing support
PrivacyPolicy.dataSharingDescription1: We do not use your personal information for any purposes other than those necessary for providing the services offered by Israquarium. Your data will not be shared with or accessible to any third parties unless required by law.
PrivacyPolicy.dataSharingDescription2: All information is used solely for the purpose of helping you maintain your virtual aquarium and providing timely notifications. We do not sell, rent, or otherwise share your personal data with any outside parties for marketing or other purposes.
PrivacyPolicy.notificationsDescription: If you opt in, we will send you email notifications about feeding schedules and cleaning times for your virtual aquarium. You can modify your notification preferences or unsubscribe at any time through your account settings.
PrivacyPolicy.dataSecurityDescription: We implement security measures to protect your data from unauthorized access, alteration, or disclosure. While we strive to protect your personal information, no method of transmission or electronic storage is 100% secure, and we cannot guarantee absolute security.
PrivacyPolicy.contactUsDescription: If you have any questions or concerns about this Privacy Policy, or if you are the owner of any content used on our website and wish to discuss its use, please contact us at:

Corydoras.title: Corydoras
Corydoras.content:
Catfish - (Callichthyidae) a genus of fish from the Callichthyidae family.

Origin:
Central America, northern and central parts of South America.

General Information:
Approximately 145 species defined by scientific names are known, and about 130 species that have not yet been identified.
Corydoras classification is based on color, body shape, and natural habitat location.
In 1970, Nijssen divided them into 9 groups based on color:
1. Corydoras punctatus (with dark spots on the body and head)
2. C. barbatus (with brownish spots on the upper and lower sides of the body)
3. C. aeneus (with a grayish-blue color on the upper half of the body)
4. C. nattereri (with a dark stripe separating the back and belly)
5. C. eques (with a dark stripe along the upper part of the body)
6. C. acutus (with grayish tones and a serrated pectoral fin)
7. C. elegans (with a longitudinal stripe in brownish shades)
8. C. caudimaculatus (with a dark spot near the tail)
9. C. hastatus (particularly small-bodied Corydoras).
In 1980, Nijssen & IsbrÃ¼cker reduced the groups to five based on similar principles. Further minor changes were made by them in 1983 and 1986, and in 1993, Burgess also contributed modifications. All these were based on color, body shape, and natural habitat.
In 1992-1993, C. Oliveira studied the chromosome count of approximately 30 species, finding the count ranged from 46 to 102. In 2002-2003, Marcelo R. Britto analyzed skull bones of various Corydoras species, revealing differences in skull structures across different species.
Corydoras are typically raised in still or slowly moving waters. They thrive in clean water and prefer slightly acidic to soft water conditions, though they adapt well to harder, alkaline water. Water temperature should be 20-26Â°C.
Corydoras feed only on the bottom, sifting through the substrate for food, and thus, gravel should be small-grained (2-4 mm). They are sensitive to any damage to their whiskers, which can easily become injured. Corydoras prefer live food but will eat most sinking freshwater fish foods.
Corydoras are social fish and do well in groups of at least 4-5. They are very sensitive to even small amounts of salt in the water.

Apistogramma.title: Apistogramma
Apistogramma.content:
(Cichlidae) a genus of fish from the Cichlidae family, subfamily Geophaginae.

Origin:
Tropical and subtropical regions of South America.

General Information:
As of 2004, around 64 species of Apistogramma are known by scientific names, with several more species awaiting identification.
In 1962, Meinken divided Apistogramma into 5 groups based on eye diameter and face length. This classification lasted for almost 20 years. In 1980, Kullander expanded the division into 7 groups, adding more distinguishing characteristics.
In 1982, Schmettkamp introduced a system of 9 groups based on habitat and added an additional group for species that did not fit into the existing groups.
Koslowski divided Apistogramma into complexes in 1985, and this monophyletic classification is still in use today.
The current division includes 13 groups and 14 complexes:
1. Apistogramma regani group (5 complexes)
2. Apistogramma sp. Rotpunkt
3. Apistogramma macmasteri group
4. Apistogramma steindachneri group
5. Apistogramma borellii group
6. Apistogramma pertensis group
7. Apistogramma sp. Balzfleck
8. Apistogramma diplotaenia
9. Apistogramma agassizii group
10. Apistogramma gibbiceps group
11. Apistogramma cacatuoides group
12. Apistogramma trifasciata group
13. Apistogramma sp.
Apistogrammas are typically territorial, especially during breeding. They are relatively peaceful with other small fish and inhabit the bottom third of the aquarium.

Barbus.title: Barbus
Barbus.content:
(Cyprinidae) a genus of fish from the Cyprinidae family.

Origin:
Asia, Africa, Europe.

General Information:
In the mid-20th century, most species were classified under the genera Barbus and Puntius. American ichthyologist L.P. Shultz divided the group into four genera:
1. Barbus (Cuvier, 1816)
2. Barbodes (Bleeker, 1859)
3. Capoeta (Valenciennes, 1842)
4. Puntius (Hamilton, 1822)
This classification was based on the number of pairs of barbels the fish had.
Most Barbus species in aquariums today are from Asia, though the genus also includes species from Africa and Europe. Sizes range from 1.5 cm to 2 meters, but most aquarium species are 5-9 cm in length.
Barbus species are generally schooling fish that prefer to swim in groups. They require spacious aquariums with plenty of plants, logs, and rocks to provide hiding places.

Rainbowfish.title: Rainbowfish
Rainbowfish.content:
Melanotaeniidae, a family of fish known as rainbowfish.

Origin:
Australia, Oceania, including Indonesia, New Guinea, and nearby islands.

General Information:
Rainbowfish belong to six genera: Cairnsichthys, Chilatherina, Glossolepis, Iriatherina, Melanotaenia, and Rhadinocentrus. Approximately 70 species of rainbowfish are currently recognized.
Rainbowfish are known for their bright, colorful bodies, often with stripes. Sizes range from 6 to 16 cm, with their body depth reaching up to 40% of their total length.
Rainbowfish are social fish, best kept in groups in spacious aquariums with ample free swimming space and plants for cover. They thrive in various water conditions but prefer slightly acidic to neutral water with a temperature range of 22-28Â°C.

Nannostomus.title: Nannostomus
Nannostomus.content:
(Lebiasinidae) a genus of small fish from the Lebiasinidae family.

Origin:
Small rivers and streams in South America.

General Information:
Nannostomus species are small, elongated fish. Some species possess a small adipose fin, while others do not. Common species include Nannostomus beckfordi and Nannostomus unifasciatus.
They are peaceful fish that prefer planted aquariums with low light levels. Nannostomus are sensitive to water hardness and pH, requiring soft, slightly acidic water for successful maintenance and breeding.

Botia.title: Botia
Botia.subtitle: Gray , 1831
Botia.content:
(Botiinae) a subfamily of fish from the Cobitidae family.

Origin:
Thailand, India, Pakistan, China, Japan, and some Indonesian islands.

General Information:
Currently, around 40 species of Botia are known. They range in size from 5 to 35 cm and exhibit a wide range of temperaments, from peaceful to aggressive.
Botia species are divided into four complexes based on habitat and body shape:
1. Botia Modesta Complex
2. Hyemenophysa Complex
3. Indian Botia Complex
4. Pulchra Complex

Betta.title: Betta
Betta.content:
(Osphronemidae) a genus of fish from the Osphronemidae family, subfamily Macropodinae.

Origin:
Asia â€“ mainly in Malaysia and Indonesia, with some species in Thailand, Singapore, and Vietnam.

General Information:
Currently, 47 species are described, with about 10 more awaiting description. Bettas are known for their labyrinth organ, which allows them to breathe atmospheric air.
Betta species are divided into two major groups: bubble nest builders (13 species) and mouthbrooders (34 species). These groups are further divided into 14 complexes based on external morphology, color, habitat, and breeding behavior.

Lamprologus.title: Lamprologus
Lamprologus.content:
(Cichlidae) a genus of fish from the Cichlidae family.

Origin:
Africa, mainly in Lake Tanganyika and the Congo River system.

General Information:
Lamprologus is divided into four genera: Altolamprologus, Lamprologus, Lepidiolamprologus, and Neolamprologus. These species are known for their territorial behavior, with some exhibiting shell-dwelling behavior.

Aulonocara.title: Aulonocara
Aulonocara.content:
(Cichlidae) a genus of fish from the Cichlidae family.

Origin:
Africa, Lake Malawi.

General Information:
Aulonocara are medium-sized cichlids, ranging from 8 cm to 30 cm. They are divided into two groups: 'sand dwellers' and 'rock dwellers.'
Sand-dwelling species are more peaceful, while rock-dwelling species are more territorial. Aulonocara species are known for their vibrant coloration and intricate social structures.

Julidochromis.title: Julidochromis
Julidochromis.content:
(Cichlidae) a genus of fish from the Cichlidae family.

Origin:
Africa, Lake Tanganyika.

General Information:
Julidochromis species are territorial cichlids, often living in rocky areas. They form monogamous pairs and are known for their narrow body shape and distinct stripes.

Otocinclus.title: Otocinclus
Otocinclus.subtitle: Cope 1871
Otocinclus.content:
(Loricariidae) a genus of fish from the Loricariidae family.

Origin:
Small rivers and streams in South America.

General Information:
Otocinclus species are known for their algae-eating behavior. They are peaceful, social fish that should be kept in groups of 4 or more. Otocinclus species prefer aquariums with lots of plants and clean, well-oxygenated water.

Tropheus.title: Tropheus
Tropheus.content:
(Cichlidae) a genus of fish from the Cichlidae family.

Origin:
Africa, endemic to Lake Tanganyika.

General Information:
Tropheus species are known for their specialized diet and social structure. They live in large groups and have a strict hierarchy, with one dominant male.
Tropheus are primarily herbivorous, feeding on algae. They are best kept in large aquariums with many rocks and open swimming areas.

Dicrossus.title: Dicrossus
Dicrossus.content:
(Cichlidae) a genus of fish from the Cichlidae family, subfamily Geophaginae.

Origin:
Tropical and subtropical regions of South America.

General Information:
Dicrossus are small cichlids, typically up to 10 cm in length, and live in slow-moving streams. They are relatively peaceful but require clean, soft, slightly acidic water for successful maintenance and breeding.

Loricariidae.title: Loricariidae
Loricariidae.content:
